title: AAI ATC JE Full Test 1
instruction:
General Instructions


The Test contain 5 Sections having total 120 Questions.Each question has 4 options out of which only one is correct.You have to finish the test in 120 minutes.

You will be awarded 1 mark for each correct answer and there is no negative marking.

Once you start the test, you will not be allowed to reattempt it. Make sure that you complete the test before you submit the test and/or close the browser.

quiz.text:
Direction: Select the synonym of the word "jealous" that is mentioned in bold:

She is jealous of me. She left my lecture at 9 p.m.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'envious​.'

Key Points 

  • Let us see the meaning of Jealous:
    • Jealous: feeling or showing an envious resentment of someone or their achievements, possessions, or perceived advantages. ((किसी व्यक्ति या उनकी उपलब्धियों, संपत्ति, या कथित लाभों के प्रति ईर्ष्या की भावना को महसूस करना या दिखाना)
  • Let us see the meanings of the given options:
    • Attentive: paying close attention to something. (किसी चीज पर पूरा ध्यान देना)
    • Evolutionary: involving a gradual process of change and development. (परिवर्तन और विकास की एक क्रमिक प्रक्रिया को शामिल करना)
    • Enduring: lasting over a period of time; durable. (लंबे समय तक चलने वाला; टिकाऊ)
    • Envious: wanting something that somebody else has. (दूसरे के पास जो वस्‍तु है उसका इच्‍छुक)
  • From the meanings of the given words, we can say that the synonym of the word "jealous" that is mentioned in bold is "envious."
  • Hence, the correct answer is Option 4.

quiz.text:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.

A. Soon you would see the number increasing.

B. You cannot count them anymore.

C. How wonderful it is to watch the sky after sunset!

D. One would first notice one or two bright dots shining in the sky.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is "C, D, A, B"

Key Points

  •  Let's look at the correct sequence of the passage.
  • Statement C is the opening sentence of the passage as it introduces the theme of the passage which is how beautiful the sky looks after sunset.
  • Statement D is the second sentence of the passage as it explains the gradual visibilities of the stars after sunset.
  • Statement A is the third sentence of the passage which says that the number of stars starts increasing slowly as the visibility is proportional to darkness.
  • Statement B is the last sentence of the passage which explains that we can never count the stars as the number of stars in the galaxy is uncountable.

Hence, the correct sequence is "C, D, A, B"

The correct passage is  C. How wonderful it is to watch the sky after sunset!  D. One would first notice one or two bright dots shining in the sky.  A. Soon you would see the number increasing.  B. You cannot count them anymore.

quiz.text:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.

It was late, but since _________ moon was shining in the sky we could find our way in _______ forest.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is "the; the."

Key Points

  • In English there are three articles: a, an, and the.
  • Articles are used before nouns or noun equivalents and are a type of adjective.
  • The definite article (the) is used before a noun to indicate that the identity of the noun is known to the reader.
  • The indefinite article (a, an) is used before a noun that is general or when its identity is not known.
  • Now, in the given sentence, we know the identity of the nouns i.e. "the moon" and "the forest in which the subject was present."
  • Thus, we will use the definite article "the" in the blanks.
  • The correct sentence: It was late, but since the moon was shining in the sky we could find our way in the forest.

Hence, the correct answer is option 4.

quiz.text:
In the following sentence choose the word opposite in meaning to the italicised word to fill in the blanks:

Just incorporate the necessary details and ______ the rest.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is "Exclude".

Key Points

  •  Here the bold word is 'Incorporate' and we need to choose the antonym of this word to fill the given blank. 
  •  Incorporate means to include (something) as part of something else.
    • Example:The new cars will incorporate a number of major improvements.
  • The marked option 'Exclude' means to keep out or omit (something or someone),to not include.
    • Example: The advertised price excludes the sales tax.
  • From the above given meanings and example sentences, we are clear that 'incorporate' and 'exclude' are opposite in meaning to each other.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is option 2.

Correct Sentence :Just incorporate the necessary details and exclude the rest.

Additional Information 

  •  Differentiate : to see or show how things are different
  •  Dissect:to cut open something, especially a dead body or a plant.
  •  Disjoin :separate or disunite.

quiz.text:
Direction: Choose the best option to fill in the blank.

For ______ single-item billing in the supermarket, you need to go to ______ last counter.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'no article, the.'

Key Points 

  • The only articles in English are ‘the’ and ‘a/an’.
  • Use the article "a or an" to indicate any non-specified member of a group or category.
  • If a word begins with a vowel sound, then the correct article is 'an'; otherwise, if it begins with a consonantal sound, the correct article is 'a'.
  • The definite article 'the' is used before a noun to indicate that the identity of the noun is known to the reader. 
    • Example: 
      • We are looking for an apartment.
      • I own a cat and two dogs.
      • I love to visit the building.
  • For the second blank, we are talking about the particular "(last) counter", so we must use "the" in the second blank.
  • Also, the word "single" is used as an adjective in this sentence, so it doesn't need an article before it.
  • Now judging all the options, we can say that Option 4 is the correct answer.
     

​Correct sentence: For single-item billing in the supermarket, you need to go to the last counter.

quiz.text:
Direction: Parts of a sentence are given below in jumbled order. Identify the option that arranges the parts in the correct order to form a meaningful sentence.

To / the / Government / come / forward / must / poverty / eradicate
options: (A) The Government come forward to must eradicate poverty.
(B) Government come must forward to the eradicate poverty.
(C) The Government to eradicate must come forward poverty.
(D) The Government must come forward to eradicate poverty.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'The Government must come forward to eradicate poverty​.'

Key Points

  • While arranging the parts of the sentence given in options, we have to find some grammatical or contextual connections between them, so let’s find out.
  • In this sentence, we can see that there are different parts like Subject, indirect object, subject of subordinating clause and verb, indirect object, and direct object.
  • The first part of the answer should be "The Goverment" as it is providing a subject to the sentence.
    • "The" is used with the word "Government" when referring to a specific instance.
  • The next part will be the modal verb "must" that should be used after the subject "The Goverment."
  • The modal verb "must" is always forward by V1 form.
  • The next part must be "come forward" as it is a phrasal verb and it means to offer to give help or information.
  • The next part must be "to eradicate poverty" as the to-infinitive is used to express purpose.​
  • The last part must be the word "poverty" to provide an object to the "to infinitive."
  • Thus, the correct answer is Option 4.
     

​​Correct sentence: The Government must come forward to eradicate poverty.

quiz.text:
Direction: In the given sentence, four words have been underlined and the underlined words are given as options. Select the option that contains an error.

No singer in indebted India is as famous as the incomparable Lata Mangeshkar.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'indebted​.'
 Key Points

  • The error lies in the part "indebted" of the sentence.
  • The use of this word is incorrect in this context.
  • The meaning of the word "indebted" is committed or obligated to repay a monetary loan or grateful to someone because of help that person has given you.
    • Word "indebted" का अर्थ एक मौद्रिक ऋण चुकाने के लिए प्रतिबद्ध या बाध्य है या उस व्यक्ति द्वारा आपको दी गई सहायता के कारण किसी का आभारी है।
      • Example: For her encouragement and support, I am especially indebted to my wife, Nancy.
  • ​Therefore, the use of the word "indebted" is unsuitable in this context.
  • Instead, we can use the word "independent" which means free from and not controlled by another person, country, etc. (अन्‍य व्‍यक्ति, देश आदि के नियंत्रण से मुक्त; स्‍वाधीन, स्‍वतंत्र)
     

Correct sentence: No singer in independent India is as famous as the incomparable Lata Mangeshkar.

quiz.text:
Select the most appropriate word for the given group of words.

The art of making maps
quiz.solution:
The correcrt answer is 'Cartography'.

Key Points

  • Cartography: The art of drawing maps.
    • ​Example: Cartography first came into being hundreds of years ago.
  • English word cartography is created from carte, meaning "map," and -graphie, meaning "representation by."
  • Hence, the most appropriate one-word for the given group of words is 'Cartography'.​​

Therefore, the correct answer is "Option 2". 

Additional Information

  • Let's understand the meaning with examples of given words
    • ​Calligraphy: Decorative handwritten or Good handwritten.
      • ​Example: The letter written in admirable calligraphy.
    • Geography: The study of Earth and its features.  
    • Lexicography: The practice of compiling dictionaries.
      • ​Example: Arun decided to build his career in lexicography.

quiz.text:
Select the most appropriate option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words

Ramesh had delivered a speech without preparation, he got 1st prize in the speech competition.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is - 'Impromptu"

Key Points

  • From the given options , the most appropriate answer is 'Impromptu' it means - Done\Said something without preparation or done accidently. 
  • Let's see the meaning of other options -
    • Rehearsed means to practice something before performance
    • Scripted means something in written form
    • Planned means prepare or organize something that will be in future.

 So the correct option is Option (4)

quiz.text:
Direction: Select the part containing incorrect/unconventional/nonstandard collocation.

Managers can build / A organisational skills / B by hiring new people / C instead of getting surviving people to learn and change./ D
quiz.solution:
Here the erroneous part is "D."

Key Points 
  • The error lies in part (D) of the sentence.
  • The use of the word "surviving" is wrong in this context.
  • In the phrase "existing people", "existing" is a collocation of "people" and "surviving" would not sound natural.
  • Collocation is a word or phrase that is often used with another word or phrase, in a way that sounds correct to people who have spoken the language all their lives, but might not be expected from the meaning.
  • An "existing people" refers to the people who are already there or being used; present 
    • Example: For existing people, the presence of bad things is bad and the presence of good things is good.
  • So, we must use the word "existing" instead of the word "surviving."
     

​Correct sentence: Managers can build organisational skills by hiring new people instead of getting existing people to learn and change.

quiz.text:
In the following question, the given sentence has four parts marked as A, B, C, and D. Choose the part of the sentence with an error and mark it as your answer. If there is no error, mark D as your answer.

If I had known (A) / it earlier I will have not allowed her (B) / to enter the premises. (C) / No Error (D)
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is B

Key Points

  • Part B of the sentence is erroneous.
  • The above sentence is a conditional type of sentence that follows the following format:
    • If I had known (that) + Unknown fact + (then) different action (would / could / might have + past participle)
  • Here, in the sentence, would should be used instead of will to make the sentence grammatically correct.
     

​Hence, the correct sentence would be, If I had known it earlier I would have not allowed her to enter the premises.

Therefore, it can be inferred that the correct answer is option 2)

Additional Information 

 Some other examples of similar conditional sentences are:

  • If I had known that you were shifting to a new house, I would have helped you.
  • If I had known it would rain, I never would have gone to the party.

quiz.text:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.

Ravi told / his friends / that he would / return back soon.
quiz.solution:
The erroneous part of the sentence is: return back soon

Key Points

  • Remove 'back' to make the sentence correct.
  • The word back is implied by the word return, so basically it is not needed to use back.
  • The word 'Return' itself means to come or go back to a previous place, subject, activity, or condition.
  • The prefix “re” in English means 'back' or 'again'. So, there is no need to use 'back'.

Therefore, the correct answer is option 2.

Corrected sentence: Ravi told his friends that he would return soon.

quiz.text:
Direction: Below in each question, some sentences are given, find the sentence which is not really contributing to the main theme and OUT of the passage or find the odd sentence and rearrange the remaining sentences to make a coherent paragraph.

(A)  In the last one year, 62 equity schemes gave negative returns out of the 333 schemes, show data from Value Research.

(B)  The common features of the instruments available for retirement savings are that such instruments are of long-term nature and they are tax efficient.

(C) Of a total universe of 333 equity schemes, nearly 45% of the schemes has given negative returns in the last two years.

(D)  Market participants say that, going forward, investors should moderate their expectations as far as returns are concerned as Indian markets are likely remain volatile due to the slowing economic growth.

(E) ​Returns of equity schemes have been poor for the last two years due to intense polarisation seen in the markets.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is "B"

Key Points

How to attempt:

  • In this type of questions, take a bird's eye view, find out the common theme which is described in all the statements, and rearrange the jumbled up sentences. The statement which is not contributing to the main theme of the passage needs to be kept out.
  • After going through the five sentences given above, we can easily mark sentence B as the odd one because that is irrelevant to our paragraph which is mainly concerned with the poor returns of equity and shares.
  • ECAD - This arrangement forms a coherent paragraph.

The complete paragraph is given below:

Returns of equity schemes have been poor for the last two years due to intense polarisation seen in the markets. Of a total universe of 333 equity schemes, nearly 45% of the schemes has given negative returns in the last two years. In the last one year, 62 equity schemes gave negative returns out of the 333 schemes, show data from Value Research. Market participants say that, going forward, investors should moderate their expectations as far as returns are concerned as Indian markets are likely remain volatile due to the slowing economic growth.

quiz.text:
Directions: In the following question, four alternatives are given for the idiom/phrase underlined in the sentence. Choose the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the idiom/phrase.

The Social Democratic Party gained votes at the expense of possible allies but lost out to the radical rightist Swedish Democrats.
options: (A) To do something in a way that harms or neglects another thing
(B) To spend a lot of money on someone or something, usually one that you don't want to spend
(C) To be careless and jeopardize someone.
(D) To keep somebody unaware of something
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'To do something in a way that harms or neglects another thing'.

Key Points

  • If you say that 'someone does something at the expense of another thing,' you are expressing concern at the fact that they are not doing the second thing, because the first thing uses all their resources.
  • If you achieve 'something at the expense of someone,' you do it in a way which neglects them or might cause them some harm or disadvantage.
    • For example, Divyansh had no need to protect their reputation at the expense of his own.
  • So, the correct meaning of the idiom underlined given in the given sentence is 'To do something in a way that harms or neglects another thing.'

Hence, the correct answer is Option 1.

quiz.text:
Directions: Select the most appropriate meaning of the given idiom/phrase.

Need of the hour
options: (D) Most important or required thing in an urgent situation
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'Most important or required thing at an urging situation.'

Key Points

  • If something is 'the need of the hour,' it means that it is what someone needs most at a time (किसी विशेष समय पर मौजूद आवश्यकता या मांग).
    • For example, The need of the hour for India now is to make addressing child malnutrition the top priority of the government machinery all year around.
  • So, the correct meaning of the idiom 'Need of the hour' is Most important or required thing in an urgent situation.

Hence, the correct answer is Option 4.

Additional Information

  • Sufficient to serve the purpose ⇒ Good enough for Jazz, Can cut the mustard.

quiz.text:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.

Where did you have your early education? ______ the Delhi Public School.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is "at."

Key Points

  • Let us first understand the usage of the given prepositions:
    • "From" is used to show where somebody/something starts Or used to show what the origin of somebody/something is.
      • Example: Has the train from Mumbai arrived?
    • "On" is used to talk about something in or into a position covering, touching or forming part of a surface.
      • Example: There is a stain on your skirt.
    • "In" is used to talk about something at a point within an area or a space.
      • Example: I read about the accident in the paper.
    • "At" is used to say where something/somebody is or where something happens.
      • Example: They arrived late at the airport.
  • In the given sentence, the early education of the subject took place at some place.
  • Thus, the correct preposition to use in the blank is "at."
  • The correct sentence: Where did you have your early education? At the Delhi Public School.

​Hence, the correct answer is option 4.

quiz.text:
In each of the following questions, there are six sentences marked S1, P, Q, R, S, S6. The positions of S1 & S6 are fixed. You are required to choose one of the four alternatives which would be the most logical sequence of the sentences in the passage.
S1 - Many people
P - that the government can always pay out money quite easily,
Q - that the government can only pay out money
R - seem to think
S - but they forget
S6 - that it has received in taxes.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is "RPSQ"

Key Points 

  • We do not need to find any introductory sentence because the 1st sentence is fixed.
  • The sentence S1 starts with "many people" which is a noun
  • "Many people" will be the subject of this sentence:
    • Many people
  • The verb comes after the noun, the next part tells that many people think something. "Think" is a verb, so R will be the next part
    • seem to think
  • The sentence P sums up what people think about the government
    • that the government can always pay out money quite easily,
  • The next 2 parts will be S and Q because it uses the conjunction “but” and at the same time they tell the reality of the government which is quite opposite to what people think
    • but they forget
    • that the government can only pay out money
    • S6 - that it has received in taxes.
Hence, the correct passage: S1 - Many people. R - seem to think P - that the government can always pay out money quite easily, S - but they forget Q - that the government can only pay out money.

quiz.text:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.

Even after a day long discussion, the meeting remained _______.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'inconclusive'

Key Points

  •  Inconclusive (अनिर्णायक) means indecisive/ not leading to a firm conclusion or result; not ending doubt or dispute.
    • ​Ex- We have an inconclusive argument regarding the tax returns.
  • As per the context of the sentence the most appropriate word that fits the blank is inconclusive.
    ​Hence the correct answer is 'Option 3'.

Additional Information

  •  Let us see the meaning of other words:
  • inconvertible not able to be changed in form
    incompatible

    different in nature as to be incapable of coexisting.
    incomparable without an equal in quality or extent; matchless.

quiz.text:
Convert the following sentence into the Present Perfect tense.

Rakhi had created a ruckus in the hotel building.
options: (A) Rakhi has created a ruckus in the hotel building.
(B) Rakhi created a ruckus in the hotel building.
(C) Rakhi have created a ruckus in the hotel building.
(D) Rakhi had been created a ruckus in the hotel building.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is Rakhi has created a ruckus in the hotel building.

Key Points

  • The given sentence is in Past Perfect tense.
  • The present perfect tense is used:
    • For past actions when we think of their effect on the present.
      • Example: I have cleaned the glass jar. (It is clean now.)
    • For actions that happen only a short time ago. (with just)
      • Example: She has just gone out.
    • For indefinite actions that happened in a period leading up to the present time (often with already, ever, never, yet, twice, four times, etc.)
      • Example: Have you ever seen the TV series Friends?
    • For actions beginning at some time in the past and going on up to the moment of speaking (with ‘since’ and ‘for’ phrases)
      • Example: I have known him since childhood.
  • The structures go like: 
    • Subject(I/You/We/They) + have + Past participle Form of the Verb(V3)
    • Subject(He/She/It) + has + Past participle form of the verb(V3) 
  • ​​According to the above format the correct converted sentence is: Rakhi has created a ruckus in the hotel building.

Hence, the correct choice is option 1.

quiz.text:
Directions Each question below consists of a word in capital letters followed by four words or group of words. Select the word or group of words that is most similar in meaning to the words in capital letters.

MUNIFICENT
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is: Generous

Key Points

  • Let's look at the meaning of the given words
    • Munificent: Characterized by great liberality
    • Generous: Liberal in giving
    • Well to do: Having more than adequate financial resources
    • Respectable: Decent or correct in character or behavior
    • Learned: Having acquired much knowledge through studies.
  • Here, the word that is most similar in meaning to munificent is generous.
  • Thus, option 2 is correct here.

​The correct word is: Generous

Additional Information

  • Let's look at some of the synonyms of 'Munificent'
    • Freehearted, fulsome, liberal etc.
  • Let's look at some of the antonyms of 'Munificent'
    • ​Illiberal, penurious, costive etc.
